title: After woman shoots her attacker, Rep. Dan Crenshaw draws backlash for his take on universal background checks
text:
ABC News reported Tuesday that a young woman opened fire on five men trying to rob her. She was unharmed, while at least one of the bad guys was shot.

Five men tried to rob a young woman this morning. They didn’t expect her to grab her handgun and fire. Today, she is unharmed, and at least one suspect is shot. Exclusive #ABC13 interview at 4:30 & 6. https://t.co/OW8oZoQTkQ #Hounews pic.twitter.com/IS8htwfx7t — Miya Shay (@ABC13Miya) September 3, 2019

Texas Republican and passionate gun-rights advocate Dan Crenshaw said in a tweet that stories like this “are why we protect the 2nd Amendment.” OK, fair enough. A reasonable take, sure. He didn’t leave it there, though — and this is when things went sideways:

‘With universal background checks, I wouldn’t be able to let my friends borrow my handgun when they travel alone like this. We would make felons out of people just for defending themselves.’

The internet’s collective response:

The general sentiment: Should we be able to loan out guns? Are Crenshaw’s friends trained to handle the weapons? If so, don’t they have their own? Etc. Of course, not everybody took issue with his stance, but it was the critics that made Crenshaw a trending topic on Twitter TWTR, -1.04% on Wednesday.

ABC News political analyst Matthew Dowd asked, “Would you loan your car to someone with no license or insurance?” And former NFL QB Sage Rosenfels wrote, “Dan treats guns like tennis racquets.”

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who has tangled on social media with Crenshaw in the past, also chimed in, drawing plenty of backlash of her own when she made some assumptions about his pals:

You are a member of Congress. Why are you “lending” guns to people unsupervised who can’t pass a basic background check?



The people you’re giving a gun to have likely abused their spouse or have a violent criminal record, & you may not know it.



Why on earth would you do that? https://t.co/TQFjcLQebO — Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (@AOC) September 4, 2019

Crenshaw earlier this year opposed a universal-background-check bill, claiming the law wouldn’t have prevented ”all of the tragedies we’ve seen.”

He explained his view here:

The truth about universal background checks and today’s vote. pic.twitter.com/koigvhKKYT — Rep. Dan Crenshaw (@RepDanCrenshaw) February 27, 2019

Elisa Cardnell, a Democrat running against Crenshaw in 2020, also had a problem with his take. “If you can’t pass a background check, you shouldn’t have a gun. It’s as simple as that,” she told ThinkProgress. “This is all part of a repeated pattern of dangerous and irresponsible rhetoric from him regarding gun safety.”
